course_title: Advanced Studies in Human Resource Management

learning_outcomes.description: Critically synthesiseevidence from HRM and related disciplines to develop theoretically-grounded analyses of complex organisational phenomena.
Critique research methodologies in HRM scholarship, evaluating their ethical foundations, methodological rigour, and implications for evidence-based practice.
Integrate theory and practice through the development of scholarly reasoning and emerging research identity.
Design a systematic approach to synthesising scholarly literature, identifying gaps and formulating research questions that advance HRM knowledge.
Construct and defend scholarly arguments that translate research evidence into actionable recommendations for HRM challenges.

assessments.task_description:
Individually, you will prepare a ten (10) minute presentation that critically analyses a chosen data-driven paper in the context of other relevant literature, and with reference to the method(s) used and the practical application of the findings in organisational settings. 

This paper can be chosen from literature addressing any topics scheduled for the course over the semester and should draw upon your understanding of research in HRM, either quantitative, qualitative, or mixed-methodology. 

Your presentation will be followed by a formative ten (10) minute viva voce. This ungraded component provides structured practice in defending scholarly arguments before the summative viva in Assessment 3, and supports your development in articulating and justifying your analytical choices. 

In the early weeks of semester, we will build the skills of critical analysis and you will be expected to actively contribute to our discussions on a weekly basis to demonstrate your growing understanding of HRM literature. 

Your presentation materials will be submitted 24 hours prior to the delivery of your presentation at our seminar in Week 7. Your submission should include any visuals you use to explain your analysis (e.g., PowerPoint slides) and accompanying notes of your key points to be presented. 

You must integrate and cite at least three (3) other relevant, good quality, peer-reviewed articles or academic book chapters.

assessments.task_description:
Following the presentation of a complex organisational issue, you will individually choose an aspect to focus on and formulate a relevant research question. 

You will then conduct a systematic literature review to identify and synthesise a core set of literature to help you explain what can be reliably said about your chosen focus. 

From your synthesis of the literature, you will develop a research proposal that will be targeted at further academic research to address a gap you have identified in the literature. 

Your deliverable for this assessment is a 3,000-word written research proposal. This standalone written assessment recognises the substantial scholarly work required to design a rigorous research study, including systematic literature synthesis, methodological design, and ethical considerations. 

The oral presentation and defence of your research proposal is assessed separately in Assessment 3: Research Proposal Defence.

assessments.task_description:
You will present and defend your research proposal in a 30-minute session comprising: 

  1. Oral Presentation (15 minutes, 15%): Present a summary of your research proposal, including your research question, literature synthesis, proposed methodology, and the contribution of your proposed research. 
  2. Viva Voce (15 minutes, 15%): Respond to questions about your proposal, demonstrating your ability to explain, contextualise, and defend your research design under questioning. The viva voce assesses your capacity to articulate the scholarly reasoning underpinning your proposal and respond to critique. 

This assessment is identity-verified. The viva voce component directly supports the course learning outcome requiring you to construct and defend scholarly arguments.
